awd_titl_txt: CRCNS: Collaborative Research: Probabilistic Representation of Dynamic Action and Superposition in Spinal Cord Neural Populations - Advancing Theory and Experiment
awd_abstract_narration:
The operation of the brain is not 'clockwork', but rather probabilistic. The project will provide proof of concept data for a new theoretical and experimental framework that utilizes this feature, by using stochastic dynamic operators (SDOs). These new methods have potential to significantly improve predictions of dynamics from recordings of brain function, which in turn would have significant technological and medical impacts in areas including disease process diagnosis, disease control using stimulation, robot prostheses and brain machine interface designs, neural prostheses, and neurally-driven augmentation or replacement.  The project brings together a collaboration between an applied mathematician/neurologist and a comparative neurophysiologist, and will provide interdisciplinary graduate and postdoctoral training at the cutting edge of neuroscience, stochastic methods and control. 

Increasing sophistication of brain recording technology is not fully matched by an equally sophisticated mathematical approach that permits modeling and direct prediction of the relation between behavior and the activity of neural populations. For motor systems, the primary goal is control of dynamics in the environment. The methods under investigation avoid the usual neural separation into sensory and motor effects. They treat neural activity as representing probabilistic alterations of unfolding dynamics. More specifically, the SDO framework considers neural activity as causing a modification of the overall system dynamics, so that the resulting dynamics (including movement, compliance, and oscillatory behavior) achieve a desired result. This allows principled engineering solutions and use of 'big' neural activity to predict dynamics. The proof of concept proposal will test model prediction responses during trajectory formation and perturbation in reflex behavior, prediction of real-time effect of single spikes, and combined effect of multiple neurons/populations. On proof of concept project completion: (1) The SDO framework will be compared with classical techniques using novel data sets; (2) Basic feasibility of real-time robot control from spinal neural activity in a model system will be  assessed. Together, these data will all add significantly to neural analysis, neurotechnology and understanding of the novel methods in relation to others.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit results:

This project was a 2 year pilot collaboration of a neurophysiologist/spinal physiologist (Dr. Simon Giszter, Neurobiology, and Biomedical Engineering, Drexel University, Philadelphia) and a neural computation scientist and applied mathematician (Dr. Terence Sanger, Biomedical Engineering and Neurology, University of Southern California) who is also a pediatric neurologist.  Dr. Sanger has developed a new framework for analysis of neural recording data called stochastic dynamic operator (SDO) analysis. The idea of this technique is to assess the way neural activity relates to motor behavior in a probability-based way. Historically, the community has sought to establish causality of effect in neural recordings in an almost clock-work kind of way. This is both very painstaking and difficult, and may only be possible in certain situations that are highly controlled. The SDO method takes into account that neural activity might have different effects in different contexts and that these contexts may not all the observable in order to resolve outcomes. The analysis idea incorporates this issue and in this way also resembles the popular intuition that animals are not fully predictable. At the same time, the methods provided probabilistic predictions. The odds of outcomes can be calculated, and the most likely predictions evaluated. These predictions could be useful in a range of ways. They may be useful in prosthetics desigms, in understanding normal and disease-based neural activity, and in prediction of likely outcomes in these. The goal of the collaboration was to apply the SDO analysis strategy to neural recordings gathered in the isolated spinal cords of frogs, which show predictable behaviors with defined stochastic or unpredictable features. In addition, the project tested this SDO analysis strategy in a fully deterministic but highly complex simulation of spinal cord that incorporate a lot of what we understand of spinal cord circuits. The goal was to see how useful it was in discovering structures and answers we already knew, because they were 'baked in' to the simulations. However, the data from the simulations used were partial data, resembling what we recorded in live animals too. The simulations and simulation tools were shared by the Rybak group at Drexel University. The work was completed after a 1 year no cost extension, due to some initial technical difficulties with legacy animal recording systems. The outcomes of the studies were to exercise and test the SDO analysis methods and the data needs of these methods (important to determine how and when they would be useful), to establish their broad usefulness in circuit analyses, and to point the way to further work on the methods, further work on application tool developments to disseminate the methods.

Broader Impact results:

This project and its results have helped to train two postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students. The data and project methods have been discussed in educational materials in the classroom of the two PIs at the graduate level. In the later phases, the project enlisted a doctoral graduate student who plans to begin thesis research in the frog spinal cord, modularity and neural analyses with these SDO and other techniques.  The methods preliminary work helped to bootstrap preliminary data supporting a subsequent NIH Multiscale Modeling consortium proposal funded to further develop the methods. The project also inspired tests of applications beyond the original scope of animal data.  The expansion to health related research was accompanied by an unfunded examination of the application to these methods to clinically derived data. The shared experience using the Rybak simulation tools in this project served to cement various collaborative efforts beyond the collaborations of Giszter and Sanger, including various members of the Rybak research group. Thus, in future this NSF funded CRCNS pilot and its results may have broad impacts, including in human health, collaborative networks, and research interactions.
